nodes.text: Government debt (internal and external) alters the long-run competitive equilibrium in a neoclassical growth model and can change individual utility; the paper compares these effects and their mechanisms

Method: Overlapping generations model with two-period-lived individuals, infinite horizon, constant returns to scale production F(K,L)=L f(k), no depreciation, discrete time, population growth rate n, lump-sum taxes on young, one-period government debt rolled to keep debt-labor ratio constant

Assumption: Government debt issued either externally or internally is one-period maturity, pays current interest rate; debt-labor ratio is held constant (debt grows at rate n) so long-run effects are nonvanishing
Claim: Competitive equilibrium in this OLG economy can be dynamically inefficient (capital-labor ratio may exceed the Golden Rule) even absent usual market failures

Claim: Effects of debt depend on type and initial relation between interest rate r and growth rate n; when r>n (efficient case) debt generally reduces individual lifetime utility, while when r<n (inefficient case) debt can increase or ambiguously affect utility

Method detail: Market equilibrium determined by individual saving s(w,r) from life-cycle utility, aggregate supply S = L s(w,r), capital demand r = f'(k); factor-price frontier w = f(k)-kf'(k) relates w and r; stability requires derivative conditions on the implied r dynamics

Claim: External debt affects the domestic economy only through taxes needed to finance interest paid abroad and the consequent shift in the supply side of capital (reducing disposable wage and savings), which alters long-run equilibrium r and w

Claim: Internal debt affects both the supply side (via taxes) and demand side of the capital market because government borrows domestically and thus substitutes government debt for physical capital in private portfolios, directly reducing the capital stock

Result / Example: With Cobb-Douglas technology and log utility example, derived saving and equilibrium conditions show that competitive r may be greater or less than growth rate n depending on parameters, illustrating possible efficiency or inefficiency

Result / External debt: In the normal efficient case (r>n) an increase in external debt raises equilibrium r (moves r away from n), lowers net wage after taxes, reduces savings and capital stock, and decreases lifetime utility of an individual in long-run equilibrium

Result / External debt in inefficient case: If the competitive solution is dynamically inefficient (r<n), external debt can move r toward the Golden Rule and thus may increase individual utility or have ambiguous effects

Result / Internal debt: Internal debt raises equilibrium r (by increasing government demand for funds), substitutes paper for physical capital in private portfolios lowering the capital-labor ratio, and in the efficient case (r>n) lowers individual lifetime utility, with ambiguous effects in the inefficient case

Claim / Debt swap: Replacing external debt by internal debt (debt swap) raises the domestic interest rate, leaves taxes unchanged, lowers the capital-labor ratio, and thus lowers utility in the efficient case but may raise or lower utility in the inefficient case depending on magnitudes

Conclusion: Taxes required to service debt have the same direct incidence whether debt is internal or external, but internal debt has an additional negative effect by substituting government paper for productive capital; overall, in the typical efficient case internal debt is more harmful to long-run individual utility than external debt

Limitation / Robustness: Qualitative signs depend on capital market slope and stability assumptions; an alternative stability case (analyzed in appendices) can reverse direction of effects, so results are conditional on model assumptions
